definition: to guard/to defend/to keep watch/to abide by the law/to observe (rules or ritual)/nearby/adjoining

sentences.english: The team was thrown on(to) the defensive as their opponents rallied.
sentences.chinese: 該隊在對手重整旗鼓後，被迫採取守勢。

sentences.english: But this deference may not last.
sentences.chinese: 但這樣的守勢不會持續太久。

sentences.english: The Obama administration is now on the defensive.
sentences.chinese: 奧巴馬政府現在處於守勢。

sentences.english: Makers of business applications are also on the defensive.
sentences.chinese: 業務應用提供商也採取了守勢。

sentences.english: Premier Wen Jiabao talks of reform but faces conservative resistance.
sentences.chinese: 溫家寶總理談及改革，但遭受來自保守勢力的阻力。

sentences.english: Communist Party conservatives abhor the idea of condoning explicit sex.
sentences.chinese: 黨內的保守勢力痛恨對赤裸性愛內容的寬容。

definition: lit. to settle accounts after autumn/settle scores at an opportune moment (idiom)
lit. killing the chicken to warn the monkey (idiom)/fig. to punish an individual as an example to others/pour encourager les autres

(neologism c. 2013) organized disruption of healthcare facilities or verbal and physical abuse of medical staff, by an aggrieved patient or proxies such as family members or hired thugs, typically aimed at obtaining compensation
lit. to kill the chicken to get the eggs (idiom)/fig. to kill the goose that lays the golden eggs
the four great Chinese inventions: paper, printing, magnetic compass and gunpowder
villains collude together (idiom); to work hand in glove with sb (to nefarious ends)
please excuse me for not complying/to politely decline
